survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: PART 1: At any point in time since this child was born, has this child seen or been present when the following experiences happened? Please include past and present experiences. Please note, some questions have more than one part separated by "OR." If any part of the question is answered "Yes," then the answer to the entire question is "Yes." Tally the number of statements that are TRUE for this child and enter the number in the box at the end of the list.

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has your child ever lived with a parent/caregiver who went to jail/prison?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Do you think your child ever felt unsupported, unloved, and/or unprotected?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever lived with a parent/caregiver who had mental health issues? 
(for example, depression, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, PTSD, or an anxiety disorder)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has a parent/caregiver ever insulted, humiliated, or put down your child?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has the child's biological parent or any caregiver ever had, or currently has, a problem with too much alcohol, street drugs, or prescription medications use?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever lacked appropriate care by any caregiver? 
(for example, not being protected from unsafe situations, or not cared for when sick or injured even when the resources were available)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever seen or heard a parent/caregiver being screamed at, sworn at, insulted, or humiliated by another adult?

Or has your child ever seen or heard a parent/caregiver being slapped, kicked, punched, beaten up, or hurt with a weapon?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has any adult in the household often or very often pushed, grabbed, slapped, or thrown something at your child?

Or has any adult in the household ever hit your child so hard that your child had marks or was injured?

Or has any adult in the household ever threatened your child or acted in a way that made your child afraid that they might be hurt?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever experienced sexual abuse?
(for example, anyone touched your child or asked your child to touch that person in a way that was unwanted, or made your child feel uncomfortable, or anyone ever attempted or actually had oral, anal, or vaginal sex with your child)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Have there ever been significant changes in the relationship status of the child's caregiver(s)?
(for example, a parent/caregiver got a divorce or separated, or a romantic partner moved in or out)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Part 1: TOTAL

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: PART 2: At any point in time since this child was born, has this child seen or been present when the following experiences happened? Please include past and present experiences. Please note, some questions have more than one part separated by "OR." If any part of the question is answered "Yes," then the answer to the entire question is "Yes." Tally the number of statements that are TRUE for this child and enter the number in the box at the end of the list.

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever seen, heard, or been a victim of violence in your neighborhood, community, or school?
(for example, targeted bullying, assault or other violent actions, war or terrorism)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child experienced discrimination?
(for example, being hassled or made to feel inferior or excluded because of their race, ethnicity, gender identity, sexual orientation, religion, learning differences, or disabilities)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text:
Has your child ever had problems with housing?
(for example, being homeless, not having a stable place to live, moved more than two times in a six-month period, faced eviction or foreclosure, or had to live with multiple families or family members)

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Have you ever worried that your child did not have enough food to eat or that the food for your child would run out before you could buy more?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has your child ever been separated from their parent or caregiver due to foster care or immigration?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has your child ever lived with a parent/caregiver who had a serious physical illness or disability?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener
item_text: Has your child ever lived with a parent or caregiver who died?

survey_name: Pediatric ACEs and Related Life Events Screener

We are interested how often, independently, and easily your child shows each behavior when occasions call for it. Children who excel at a specific behavior should receive the highest rating ("almost always"), whereas most children will be between "frequently/often" and "sometimes". Those who are still developing and need a lot of support should receive a "rarely" rating.
Pays attention when an adult is explaining or showing something ... (by listening carefully and/or watching the adult's demonstration with appropriate eye gaze/body orientation.)
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Finishes an assigned task that is repetitive (e.g., picking up toys, putting away laundry)
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Remains focused and engaged during lengthy adult-led activities (e.g., religious or performance event, family meal time) by listening carefully and contributing when appropriate.
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Remains focused and engaged during collaborative child-led activities (e.g., playing with siblings/peers)
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Persists on a difficult task (e.g., homework, chore) by trying to figure things out, asking questions, and not quitting
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Gets deeply engaged in an activity they choose for themselves (e.g., drawing, reading, cooking, building, sports, games)
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Ignores irrelevant activity/noise (e.g., crying sibling, TV, outside traffic) when working on an assigned task
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Completes an assigned task before moving to a next task
response_options_text: Almost always: shows behavior independently with ease on almost every occasion in different settings, Frequently/often: shows behavior independently with small effort on most occasions, Sometimes: shows behavior with medium effort, needs brief reminders, corrections, or support from an adult, Rarely: shows behavior with a lot of effort, needs repeated reminders, corrections, or support from an adult

item_text: Regains focus/focuses again on an assigned task when interrupted (e.g., family member asks an unrelated question or needs brief assistance)

survey_name: MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status
item_text: Instructions: Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in <country>. At the top of the ladder are the people who are the best off - those who have the most money, the most education, and the most respected jobs. At the bottom are the people who are the worst off - those who have the least money, the least education, the least respected jobs, or no job. The higher up you are on this ladder, the closer you are to the people at the very top; the lower you are, the closer you are to the people at the very bottom.

survey_name: MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status
item_text:
Where would you place yourself on this ladder?
Please place a large "X" on the rung where you think you stand at this time in your life relative to other people in <country>.

survey_name: MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status
item_text: Instructions: Think of this ladder as representing where people stand in their communities. People define community in different ways; please define it in whatever way is most meaningful to you. At the top of the ladder are people who have the highest standing in their community. At the bottom are the people who have the lowest standing in their community.

survey_name: MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status
item_text:
Where would you place yourself on this ladder?
Please place a large "X" on the rung where you think you stand at this time in your life relative to other people in your community.
Please select No or Yes to indicate whether each event has happened to you in the past year.
Health:
An injury or illness which kept you in bed a week or more, or sent you to the hospital.
An injury or illness which was less serious than above but still sent you to the doctor or kept you in bed for a day or two.
Major dental work.
Major change in eating habits.
Major change in sleeping habits.
Major change in your usual type and/or amount of recreation.
Work:
Change to a new type of work.
Change in your work hours or conditions.
Change in your responsibilities at work (more responsibilities).
Change in your responsibilities at work (fewer responsibilities).
Change in your responsibilities at work (promotion).
Change in your responsibilities at work (demotion).
Change in your responsibilities at work (transfer).
Troubles at work (with your boss).
Troubles at work (with your coworkers).
Troubles at work (with persons under your supervision).
Other work problems.
Major business adjustment.
Retirement.
Loss of a job (laid off from work).
Loss of a job (fired from work).
Taking a course to help you with your work.
Home and Family:
Major change in living conditions.
Change in residence (move within the same town or city).
Change in residence (move to a different town, city, or state).
Change in family get-togethers.
Major change in health or behavior of family member.
Marriage.
Pregnancy.
Gain of a new family member (birth of a child).
Gain of a new family member (adoption of a child).
Gain of a new family member (a relative moving in with you).
Spouse beginning or ending work.
Child leaving home (to attend college).
Child leaving home (due to marriage).
Child leaving home (for other reasons).
Change in arguments with spouse.
In-law problems.
Change to the marital status of your parents (divorce).
Change to the marital status of your parents (remarriage).
Separation from spouse (due to work).
Separation from spouse (due to marital problems).
Divorce.
Birth of a grandchild.
Death of a spouse.
Death of other family member (child).
Death of other family member (brother or sister).
Death of other family member (parent).
Personal and Social:
Change in personal habits.
Beginning or ending school or college.
Change of school or college.
Change in political beliefs.
Change in religious beliefs.
Change in social activities.
Vacation.
New, close, personal relationship.
Engagement to marry.
Girlfriend or boyfriend problems.
"Falling out" of a close personal relationship.
An accident.
Minor violation of the law.
Death of a close friend.
Major decision regarding your immediate future.
Major personal achievement.
Financial:
Major change in finances (increased income).
Major change in finances (decreased income).
Major change in finances (investment and/or credit difficulties).
Loss or damage of personal property.
Moderate purchase.
Major purchase.
Foreclosure on a mortgage or loan.
